bboxes.raw_text:
YONKERS, N. Y. : The US.
Government, through the National
Park Service has been requested
by Educational Heritage, Inc. a
Yonkers. New York publishing
firm. to place a historical mark
er at the site where the first
Negro newspaper. Freedom
Journal was published in 1927.


Rev. Wyatt Tee Walker, Herr
tage. vice president, in letter
to Secretary Of the Interior, Stew
art Udall. asked that the Varick
Street, Manhattan be given gov
eminent recognition in tribute
to its "significance in the devel-
opment of the total American ex-
perience."


Rev. Walker, former executive
assistant to DR.. Martin Luther
King, Jr., said in his letter to
Mr.. Udall that the Negro press
and its ally the Negro church had
been a maj or force in shaping the
Nations destiny. Both institu-
tions, he wrote have additionally
taken leadership role wherever
Negroes have made any mea-
surable social gains" Recogni-
ton of this kind would become
"an effective catalyst in broden-
ing Americas knowledge about
America" he concluded.


The request to the Interior
Department head, came as part
of Mr.. Walkers suggestion to
the National Park Service that the
proposed Ellis Island. New York,
cultural site, include adequate
and we'll planned recognition of
the Negroes to Americas heri-
tage. Hitting at what he termed
the cultural blackout," now i'm
posed on Negroes, the publishing
acknowledgement, expressed
the hope that accurate portrayal
in Americas history texts was
essential in lifting a curtain of
historical untruths.''

GROUP WANTS MARKER
PLACED AT SITE OF lST
NEGRO PAPER

WASHINGTON The National
Association for the Advancement
of Colored People, at the closing
session of it's 55th annual con-
vention asked It's branches and
membership ito boycott all pro-
ducts shipped from Mississippi,
as listed by the national office
in New York City.


In the resolution adopted by
delegates the NAACP branches
and members we're also urged
"to demand that no bank, other
financial institution, or public
entity in their area seek, bid for,
or buy bonds, notes, or other
obligations of the State of Mis-
sissippi, or its municipalities"


The statement urged that units
of the Association continue such
faction in their respective COM
munities until the state and local
governments of Mississippi have,
in their law observance, returned
to the democratic, law abiding
way of life for all its citizens"

NAACP Urges
Boycott Of Ole
Miss Goods

July l7-Grand Canyon Temple
meeting.


July Is = Lawn party at the
home of Mr.. and Mrs. Arthur
Blackshear, 1907 S. 18th DR..
8 p.m.-7, Good food and cool
beverages.


July "a = Open House at Elks
Lodge, 1907 S. 9TH Ave.


July 26 = PERC meets at Doug
las. Round trip on bus for one
So. Must be paid by 10th. Come
and join US. Bus will stop at
Tombstone and Boot Hill.


Aug. 7 Regular temple meet
ing.


Aug. 9 PISA Convention COM
mittee meeting.


Aug. ii Regular Lodge meet
ing.


Aug. 2l-28 Grand lodge con-
vention at Miami, Florida; dele
gates are DIT. Ruby Blackshear-
Grand Canyon Temple: DIT. Es-
Their McElroy = Valley Of Sun
PDRC: and DIT. Maple L. Pratt
PISA.


Howard Kirk, of Phoenix, win
ner of the seventh regional ora
torical contest will compete in
the national contest in Miami.
Final rites for Bro. Arthur
ARROW, a charter member OWL
liam H. Patterson Lodge ATT
were held July 6.


The funeral of Dt. Pearl Pope,
mother Of DIT. Esther Richards
was held in Flagstaff on July IL.


Elks Reporter


C. McClammy

CHICAGO The press was
caught off guard when Mahalia
Jackson, internationally known
gospel singer, announced she had
married last Wednesday.


The famed singer was wed in
a quiet ceremony to Sig Galloway,
a Los Angeles saxophonist. Rev.
Leon jenkins. pastor of Greater
Salem Baptist Church, a close
friend of the singer, performed
the ceremony.


Miss Jackson was married
once before but she has been di-
vorced for Fl years.


Minters Sigmund Galloway, the
groom, met his bride, two years
ago on the Columbia movie studio
lot in Hollywood.

MILWAUKEE = Mrs. Myrna
Smith was jailed for pouring
hot grease on her husband while
he slept.


Mrs. Smith, q, was angered
because her husband, Clifton. %,
had accused her of supposedly
counting other men. He fled from
the house and neighbors called
an ambulance. Mr.. Smith re-
ceived serious burns on the hands
and face.

Woman PoUrs Hot
Grease On n usbu nd

director of the /. G. Homes Unit,
Boys Club, is attending a two
Bows Club Director At Reserve Comp

week training program of the
army reserve at Fl. Irwin in
Bakersfield, Calf.

guests honored dinner party last week
home of Mrs. Margie Jones, 1888 w. Madison.


Mesdames Jones' ressia Jackson Dorothy Hawkins
Opal Franks Flagstaff Mr.. and Mrs. Johnnie Stewart of South
Gwendoyn Smell.
